 REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF THE PRESIDENT
TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN
AND A TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANT TO THE ISLAMIC
REPUBLIC OF PAKISTAN FOR THE CHASHM.A RIGHT BANK
IRRIGATION PROJECT

I submit to the Board of Directors, for their consideration

1.
and decision, the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan from the Special Funds resources of the Bank in an amount in
various currencies equivalent to $3 1. 5 million and a proposed technical
assistance grant in an amount in various currencies equivalent to
$150, 000, applied for by the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the
Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Project. The loan would have a term
of 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with a service charge
of 1 per cent per annum.

I. INTRODUCTION

The Government of Pakistan has requested the Bank to

2.
finance the foreign exchange cost and part of the local currency cost
of the Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Project, and for technical
assistance to assist the Government of Pakistan and the concerned
Provincial Governments in the preparation of feasibility studies for
agricultural processing facilities in the Project area. The Project
is located on the right (west) bank of the Indus River spanning the
North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) and the Province of Punjab,
and represents the first phase of the overall Chashma Right Bank
Irrigation Scheme. The Government of Pakistan and the Provincial
Governments have accorded high priority to the agricultural development
of the area.

A feasibility study for the Project was prepared by the Water

3.
and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) in 1970, and this report
was updated in 1973. The Bank sent Fact-Finding Missions to Pakistan
in October 1976 and June 1977 to discuss the technical aspects of the
Project with the concerned government agencies. A Bank Appraisal
Mission visited the country from 1 to 23 August 1977. Formal loan
negotiations were held in Manila from 9 to 16 November 1977 with
duly authorized representatives of the Government of the Islamic
Republic of Pakistan, the Provincial Governments of NWFP and Punjab,
and WAPDA. If approved, the proposed Project would be the nd.neteenth
Bank loan project in Pakistan and the first Bank-assisted irrigation
project in that country.

II. THE ECONOMY

An Economic Report on Pakistan (Report No. PAK:Ec-5)

4.
was circulated to the Board in March 1977. This chapter summarizes
the current situation and prospects. The Basic Data are given in
Appendix 1.

A. Recent Developments

Widespread floods in August 1976 and political difficulties
5.
in the later part of the fiscal year 1976/77 caused major setbacks in
the achievements of targets both in agriculture and industry. The
estimated growth rate of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for 1976/77
was 0. 5 per cent, compared with 3. 8 per cent in 1975/76. With the
population growing at the rate of 3 per cent per annum, the per capita
GNP, estimated in 1976 at $170, !/ has declined in real terms in 1977.

The agricultural sector accounts for about 35 per cent of

6.
GDP, 80 per cent of foreign exchange earnings, and about 55 per cent
of the total labor force. Agricultural production in 1976/77 was
affected by the floods and registered an increase of only 1. 0 per
cent. Most of the increase was due to a record 8. 9 million tons of
wheat production, a gain of 3. 6 per cent over the previous year.
However, the overall agricultural index showed little increase
because floods devastated the cotton crop reducing output from a
projected 4 million bales to 2. 4 million bales.

Domestic production of wheat has been inadequate to meet

7.
the nation's requirements; more. than 6 millon tons of wheat was
imported over the period 1970/71-1976/77, although approximately
650, 000 tons of rice are exported each year. Average yields of crops
are low due to traditional cultural practices and short supply of
agricultural inputs. The country's agricultural development policy
calls for increased production of important food and cash crops through
provision of agricultural inputs, improvements of irrigation and other
facilities, and strengthening of agricultural research and extension

services. Agriculture is accorded high priority in the forthcoming
Fifth Development Plan, expected to start in 1978, to achieve
self-sufficiency in wheat and increased exports of cotton and rice.

The output of the manufacturing sector, which contributes

be seriously affected by shortages of electric power and domestic

21 per cent for the first three quarters of 19 76/77, a rate marginally

rapidly. The rate of inflation which reached a peak at 30 per cent in
197 3/74 declined to 12 per cent in 19 75/76 and to 9 per cent in
1976/77.

These deficits were fin9.nced mainly by assistance from the Pakistan

Tax collection has improved and attempts have been made to control
non-development expenditures. However, while the subsidies bill has

The ratio is, however, expected to rise to about 18 per cent for 1976/77

The extensive floods in August 1976 upset projections of

the draft Fifth Five Year Plan originally planned for implementation
in 1976/77. A new Fifth Development P1ancovering a six-year period

terms of trade.

B. Irrigation Sector

Having an arid to semi-arid climate, Pakistan's

15.
agriculture has to depend largely on various irrigation schemes from
surface and groundwater resources. Thus, the country, has over the
years, developed a network of various irrigation facilities. The Indus
Waters Treaty on the sharing of the waters of the Indus River and its
tributaries was signed by India and Pakistan in September 1960. Together
with the Treaty, the Indus Basin Development Fund was established with
the assistance of IBRD and  six governments!/to finance a program of
works, namely, the Indus Basin Project. The major works under the
Indus Basin Project include construction of two large earth-filled
dams at Mangla and Tarbela, eight inter-river link canals and several
barrages. In addition to the large external assistance received for
the Indus Basin Project, the development of irrigation water resources
in Pakistan has been assisted so far by IDA, UNDP and USAID.

The irrigation systems in Pakistan consist of about 38, 000

16.
miles (60, 800 km.) of canals, a number of barrages and dams, and
more than 150, 000 tubewells. At present, a total of about 93 million
acre feet of water is available at farm gates (63 million acre feet from
surface water and 30 million acre feet from groundwater sources). Out
of a total cultivated area of 48 million acres (ZO million ha.), about 35
million acres (14. 6 million ha.) or 73 per cent is irrigated through
canals and tubewells.

Like overall agricultural activities, water resource

17.
development has so far been concentrated in the Provinces of Punjab
and Sind, where 83 per cent and 5 1 per cent, respectively, of the
total area cultivated are irrigated at present, compared with 40 per
cent in NWFP and 41 per cent in the Province of Baluchistan. The
rain-fed cultivated area is mainly in the northern parts of Punjab and
NWFP. In these areas, the level of agricultural production is low,
and only coarse grain and other crops can be cultivated. The area to
be covered by the Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Project falls largely
in the rain-fed area; assured irrigation water supply is therefore crucial
for increased crop production.

III. BANKOPERATIONSINPAKISTAN

Bank operations in Pakistan started in 1968, when the

18.
Bank made its first loan to the Industrial Development Bank of Pakistan.
The Bank has to date approved loans aggregating $460. 82 million for 18
projects, $327.97 million from ordinary capital resources and $132. 85
million from Special Funds resources. In addition, technical assistance
for a total of $800, 000 has been approved for five projects. Three of
the technical assistance grants amounting to $500, 000 were for project
preparation. As a result of the Bank's technical assistance, two
projects, the Gas Turbine Generation Project and the Hyderabad
Water Supply and Sewerage Project have resulted in Bank loans.

The largest portion (26.4 per cent in terms of loan amount)

19.
of Bank's financial assistance has been given to the power sector
aggregating about $122 million, followed by development banks (25. 3 per
cent), industry (18 per cent), and a gas pipeline (11.5 per cent). The
largest portion of the Bank's total assistance has been directed toward
the development of energy resources, which is consistent with the
Government's policy of rapid development of energy resources to meet
increasing domestic demand. Bank assistance to the agricultural sector
includes the Rice Milling and Fisheries Development Projects.

20.
The Bank has financed three projects in Pakistan jointly
with other multilateral and bilateral agencies. The foreign exchange
cost of the Multan Fertilizer Project approved in December 1973 is

IV. THE PROJECT

A report entitled  tt Appraisal of the Chashma Right Bank
23.
Irrigation Project in Pakistan' s (Report No. PAK:Ap-22) is circulated
herewith.

One of the important surface water development programs

24.
under consideration by the Government of Pakistan is the overall
Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Scheme, which is expected to provide
perennial irrigation water for about 1.4 million acres (554, 000 ha.) by
one gravity and three separate lift irrigation works. The area is
located in the relatively less -developed region of Dera Ismail Khan
in NWFP and Dera Ghazi Khan in the Province of Punjab, on the
right (west) bank of the Indus River. In view of the large scope and
investment cost involved for this overall scheme and uncertainty in
the allocation of the required amount of water, the Government of
Pakistan has decided to phase implementation; the proposed Project,
covering an area of about 570, 000 acres (230, 000 ha.) under gravity
irrigation, constitutes the first phase of the overall scheme.

Justific atioris

Agricultural conditions in the Project area are characterized

40.
by low productivity and a consequent low standard of living among the
farmers. The main constraints are insufficient rainlall and inadequate
irrigation water as well as insufficient supporting services. About 82
per cent of the Project area is presently under dry farming where crop
production is dependent on rains. The low precipitation and its seasonal
and yearly variations have resulted in precarious farm operations; crop
failures are common and cropping intensity varies from year to year,
averaging about 26 per cent. Provision of perennial water supplies and
introduction of improved farming practices are essential for increased
agricultural production in the Project area.

 - 14 -

The Project has been formulated as an integrated

41.
agricultural development undertaking with the major objective of
increasing agricultural production and improving living conditions
in the Project area. Higher yields of crops and an increase in the
cropped area from the present 185, 000 acres to 855, 000 acres
would result in incremental crop production of about 560, 000 tons
of various food crops, thus generating net incremental benefits valued
at about $82 million equivalent at full development of the Project. The
Project is expected to yield an economic internal rate of return of
19 per cent, which is considered satisfactory. About 23, 000 farm
families, of which about 77 per cent are small farmers holding less
than 25 acres (10. 4 ha.) of land, would benefit from the Project. The
Project would create employment opportunities for about 11 million
man-days during its five-year construction period and 29 million man-
days of farm labor annually thereafter.

Investment in the Project is justifiable both in terms of
42.
net value added to the national economy as well as the financial gains
to the farm families and other socio -economic benefits. The proposed

B. Irrigation Sector

Having an arid to semi-arid climate, Pakistan's

15.
agriculture has to depend largely on various irrigation schemes from
surface and groundwater resources. Thus, the country, has over the
years, developed a network of various irrigation facilities. The Indus
Waters Treaty on the sharing of the waters of the Indus River and its
tributaries was signed by India and Pakistan in September 1960. Together
with the Treaty, the Indus Basin Development Fund was established with
the assistance of IBRD and  six governments!/to finance a program of
works, namely, the Indus Basin Project. The major works under the
Indus Basin Project include construction of two large earth-filled
dams at Mangla and Tarbela, eight inter-river link canals and several
barrages. In addition to the large external assistance received for
the Indus Basin Project, the development of irrigation water resources
in Pakistan has been assisted so far by IDA, UNDP and USAID.

The irrigation systems in Pakistan consist of about 38, 000

16.

more than 150, 000 tubewells. At present, a total of about 93 million
acre feet of water is available at farm gates (63 million acre feet from
surface water and 30 million acre feet from groundwater sources). Out
of a total cultivated area of 48 million acres (ZO million ha.), about 35
million acres (14. 6 million ha.) or 73 per cent is irrigated through
canals and tubewells.

Like overall agricultural activities, water resource

17.
development has so far been concentrated in the Provinces of Punjab
and Sind, where 83 per cent and 5 1 per cent, respectively, of the
total area cultivated are irrigated at present, compared with 40 per
cent in NWFP and 41 per cent in the Province of Baluchistan. The
rain-fed cultivated area is mainly in the northern parts of Punjab and
NWFP. In these areas, the level of agricultural production is low,
and only coarse grain and other crops can be cultivated. The area to
be covered by the Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Project falls largely
in the rain-fed area; assured irrigation water supply is therefore crucial
for increased crop production.

Justific atioris

Agricultural conditions in the Project area are characterized

40.
by low productivity and a consequent low standard of living among the
farmers. The main constraints are insufficient rainlall and inadequate
irrigation water as well as insufficient supporting services. About 82
per cent of the Project area is presently under dry farming where crop
production is dependent on rains. The low precipitation and its seasonal
and yearly variations have resulted in precarious farm operations; crop
failures are common and cropping intensity varies from year to year,
averaging about 26 per cent. Provision of perennial water supplies and
introduction of improved farming practices are essential for increased
agricultural production in the Project area.

 - 14 -

The Project has been formulated as an integrated

41.
agricultural development undertaking with the major objective of
increasing agricultural production and improving living conditions
in the Project area. Higher yields of crops and an increase in the
cropped area from the present 185, 000 acres to 855, 000 acres
would result in incremental crop production of about 560, 000 tons
of various food crops, thus generating net incremental benefits valued
at about $82 million equivalent at full development of the Project. The
Project is expected to yield an economic internal rate of return of
19 per cent, which is considered satisfactory. About 23, 000 farm
families, of which about 77 per cent are small farmers holding less
than 25 acres (10. 4 ha.) of land, would benefit from the Project. The
Project would create employment opportunities for about 11 million
man-days during its five-year construction period and 29 million man-
days of farm labor annually thereafter.

Investment in the Project is justifiable both in terms of
42.
net value added to the national economy as well as the financial gains
to the farm families and other socio -economic benefits. The proposed
Project is technically feasible, economically viable and socially
desirable. The Project is accorded high priority by both the Federal
and the concerned Provincial Governments in their respective develop-
ment plans, and merits the Bkik's financial assistance. The proposed
technical assistance will help the Government of Pakistan and the
Provincial Governments of NWFP and Punjab in the preparating of
feasibility studies for agricultural processing facilities in the Project

REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF THE PRESIDENT
TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN
AND A TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANT TO THE ISLAMIC
REPUBLIC OF PAKISTAN FOR THE CHASHM.A RIGHT BANK
IRRIGATION PROJECT
I submit to the Board of Directors, for their consideration
1.
and decision, the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan from the Special Funds resources of the Bank in an amount in
various currencies equivalent to $3 1. 5 million and a proposed technical
assistance grant in an amount in various currencies equivalent to
$150, 000, applied for by the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the
Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Project. The loan would have a term
of 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years, with a service charge
of 1 per cent per annum.
I. INTRODUCTION
The Government of Pakistan has requested the Bank to
2.
finance the foreign exchange cost and part of the local currency cost
of the Chashma Right Bank Irrigation Project, and for technical
assistance to assist the Government of Pakistan and the concerned
Provincial Governments in the preparation of feasibility studies for
agricultural processing facilities in the Project area. The Project
is located on the right (west) bank of the Indus River spanning the
North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) and the Province of Punjab,
and represents the first phase of the overall Chashma Right Bank
Irrigation Scheme. The Government of Pakistan and the Provincial
Governments have accorded high priority to the agricultural development
of the area.
A feasibility study for the Project was prepared by the Water
3.
and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) in 1970, and this report
was updated in 1973. The Bank sent Fact-Finding Missions to Pakistan
in October 1976 and June 1977 to discuss the technical aspects of the
Project with the concerned government agencies. A Bank Appraisal
Mission visited the country from 1 to 23 August 1977. Formal loan
negotiations were held in Manila from 9 to 16 November 1977 with
duly authorized representatives of the Government of the Islamic
Republic of Pakistan, the Provincial Governments of NWFP and Punjab,
and WAPDA. If approved, the proposed Project would be the nd.neteenth
Bank loan project in Pakistan and the first Bank-assisted irrigation
project in that country.
